Merge pull request #3520 from diox/iarc-generic-rating-fixes-2

Fix "Generic" IARC rating body to PEGI categories... without the "+"

Fix "Generic" IARC rating body to PEGI categories... without the "+"

We sadly match on AgeRatingText because it was the most convenient with
what we had when we started. It appears that for Generic, IARC rating
text no longer includes the "+" after the age, at least not always.

Merge pull request #3518 from diox/iarc-generic-rating-fixes

Merge pull request #3516 from diox/iarc-stage

Add IARC stage settings

Add all PEGI categories/descriptors to Generic rating body

As requested by IARC:
- Generic has no records in Descriptor table, it uses the complete set of PEGI descriptors
- Generic has no records in AgeRating table either, it uses the complete set of PEGI age ratings, but for ageRatingID 55 it shows a 12+ icon, i.e. when PEGI shows an exclamation point icon Generic shows “12+”.
Delete the IARCRequest object when we receive a pushcert request (bug 1250478)
Add IARC stage settings

Merge pull request #3488 from diox/only-queue-tasks-when-request-started

Don't queue tasks if we're not inside a request-response cycle (bug 1241071)

Merge pull request #3513 from diox/enable-new-iarc-constants

Add new IARC category, descriptors and interactives (bug 1247718)

Merge pull request #3512 from diox/iarc-confirm-before-attach

Show a confirmation before attaching an IARC Certificate
Add new IARC category, descriptors and interactives (bug 1247718)

Replace all our tasks by post_request_task now that it's a separate lib (bug 1241071)

post-request-task was extracted to zamboni and published in a separate lib. One
important change from before is that it only queues tasks when a request has been
started, which means there is nothing special to do anymore to launch tasks from
a management command or a django shell.

Thanks to this change I modified all our tasks to be post_requests_tasks as there
is no drawback and the added benefit is huge.

Some tests had to be updated to either delay their indexing tasks or reindex after
they did some modifications that aren't automatically triggering reindexes. We used
to not see those because the indexing was delayed or not happening at all in some
cases.

Show a confirmation before attaching an IARC Certificate

Per spec : "present the ratings information to the developer and ask if this is the cert they want to use."

2262e0822108b4c482bc03dbf5b5f25d36c207ab.

amputate restframework metadata listing

Django REST Framework 3.x provides metadata about a view in the OPTIONS
response by default. Unfortunately this includes all valid choices for
foreign-key fields, so some requests were producing all apps and all
users as part of the output. We remove this field introspection entirely.

issue_comments.body: Looks nice.
Committed with some style changes in https://github.com/jbalogh/zamboni/commit/cb68ebf

The goal for this is not just to fix Addon.objects.create but Addon.objects.get and other methods coming from the AddonManager. I want the ORM to give me a Webapp instead of an Addon when the row I'm pulling is a webapp.

I'm trying to treat these as objects that know what they need to do to themselves. I don't want Addon.save to mess with a Webapp's slug column, I want Webapp.save to mess with the app_slug column. We could make an `AddonOrWebapp` class that's really explicit, but that doesn't make for pretty code. `Webapp` inherits from `Addon` so you shouldn't need to care which one you have.

Also, I'm trying to change as little code as possible. Primarily because I'm lazy, but also because adding special cases leads to more bugs later.

Furthermore, the [Liskov Substition Principle](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liskov_substitution_principle) states that, in a computer program if S is a subtype of T, then objects of type T may be replaced with objects of type S (i.e., objects of type S may be substitutes for objects of type T), without altering any of the desirable properties of that program (correctness, task performed, etc.).

If we order by RAND() here, we'll get all the randomness we need from the db.  The downside is that the RAND() query will be cached, so followup calls will not be so random.  Once the query goes out of cache (after however long the timeout is), we'll get a new randomized list.

An alternative way to do this is:

```
try:
    addon = Addon.objects.get(pk=addon_id)
except Addon.DoesNotExist:
    return
```

This also keeps it to a single db query, whereas the `exists` and the `[0]` actually does 2 separate queries.

This ends up doing 2 queries... one for the `exists()` which looks like a "SELECT 1 FROM ..." in SQL, and then one to get the obj. It'd be more efficient (and to me, clearer) to do the following. It is more lines but 1 less query.

```
try:
    addon = Addon.objects.get(guid=guid)
except Addon.DoesNotExist:
    addon = None
```

Python has this built in:

``` python
>>> import email
>>> s = """header1: yo
... header2: yolo
...
... email starts here
...
... then I sign off
... """
>>> em = email.message_from_string(s)
>>> em.items()
[('header1', 'yo'), ('header2', 'yolo')]
>>> em._payload
'email starts here\n\nthen I sign off\n'
```

commit_comments.body: When you are jumping around tabs, the mouse events don't always trigger and clear the interval. In the instance that the interval wasn't properly cleared, we would wind up with 2 intervals would be attached, and it causes strange double-advancing behavior. Ensuring this.interval is cleared before we set a new one solves this.

I think that should be "pip install -r requirements/dev.txt -r requirements/compiled.txt"

Depending on how you want to install, you could also use `pip install --ignore-installed --install-option="--prefix=$(pwd)/vendor/"` -- that would do a full install.  I've never actually tried `--build` for this sort of thing.  Maybe it's a good alternative, I've just never really thought about it.

I'm not sure what you mean by "sourced" here?  Or... do you mean they use a nested structure where the code is like packages/selenium/src/selenium/**init**.py ?  If you use `pip install -e` it'll figure that sort of thing out (and write it to easy-install.pth).
